child.geography: Russian Federation: Bashkortostan Republic, between Volga river and Ural mountains; beyond the Urals. Also in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,150,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census), decreasing. Population total all countries: 1,221,340. Ethnic population: 2,060,000. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: All ages. Neutral attitudes. Also use Tatar [tat]. Language Development: Bible portions: 1899–2003. Statutory language of provincial identity in Bashkortostan Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.geography: Russian Federation: Tatarstan and Bashkortostan republics; Saint Petersburg and Moscow to eastern Siberia. Also in Azerbaijan, Belarus, China, Estonia, Finland, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Different from Crimean Tatar (Crimean Turkish [crh]). Population: 4,280,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). 24,700 Kreshen (Kryashen) Tatars, who are traditionally Russian Orthodox. Population total all countries: 5,407,550. Ethnic population: 5,550,000 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script. Language Use: Also used by the Karatai (different from Karata [kpt]), ethnically Erzya people who speak Tatar. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught in primary schools. Taught in secondary schools and university. Magazines. Newspapers. New media. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Statutory provincial language in Tatarstan Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Considered a 'mixed language.' 43,000 Astrakhan (L1 speakers) have shifted to the Middle dialect.

child.geography: Russian Federation: North of Altay mountains, Chulym river basin, Ob river tributary.
child.alt-names: Chulim, Chulym Tatar, Chulym-Turkish, Melets Tatar
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Similar to Shor [cjs]; some consider them one language. The government considers them separate. Population: 44 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 660 (2002 census). Language Use: Middle-aged or older. Also use Russian [rus]. Spoken in villages. Also spoken by the Kacik (Kazik, Kuarik).

child.geography: Russian Federation: South Karachay-Cherkessia Province and Kabardino-Balkaria Republic. Also in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.alt-names: Balkarian, Balqar, Karacaylar, Karachai, Karachaitsy, Karachay, Karachayla
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 305,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). 192,000 Karachay, 108,000 Balkar (2002 census). Used by 97% of the ethnic population. Population total all countries: 310,730. Ethnic population: 303,000 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Balkar and Karachay almost identical.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Dagestan Republic, north and east plain. Also in Kazakhstan, Turkey.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Different from Kumux dialect of Lak [lbe]. Population: 426,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 426,550. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Higher where majority speak Kumyk. Literacy rate in L2: High in Russian. Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. Radio programs. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Lithuania: Trakai and a few other places. Also in Ukraine.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 50 in Lithuania (Salminen 2007). Population total all countries: 56. Ethnic population: 270. Writing: Cyrillic script, used in Crimea. Latin script, used in Lithuania.

child.pub-comments: Population: 200 (Salminen 2007). 1,200 ethnic Krimchak in the Crimea, 600 elsewhere (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 1,800. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script. Language Use: Rarely used even by the elderly who know it (2007). Only those 70 years and older are fluent (2007).

child.geography: Uzbekistan: Along lower Amu Darya; south Aral Sea area. Also in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russian Federation, Turkmenistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 407,000 in Uzbekistan (1993 UBS). Population total all countries: 410,410. Ethnic population: 424,000 in what is now the Russian Federation. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script. Language Use: Also use Uzbek [uzn] or Russian [rus]. Statutory language of provincial identity in Karakalpakstan (1995, [amended] Official Language Law, 3561-XI, Article 3).

child.geography: Kyrgyzstan: Widespread. Also in Afghanistan, China, Kazakhstan, Russian Federation, Tajikistan, Turkey, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 2,450,000 in Kyrgyzstan (1993 UBS). Population total all countries: 2,941,930. Writing: Arabic script, used in China. Cyrillic script, not used in Afghanistan. Latin script, used in Turkey. Language use: L1 for 98% of Kyrgyz. The Ichkilik are a Kyrgyz-speaking people of non-Kyrgyz origin. Some also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Schools in Kyrghyz. Newspapers. Radio programs. Films. TV. Bible: 1995–2004. Statutory national language (2010, Constitution, Art 10(1)).

child.geography: Russian Federation: Northern Caucasus, Karachay-Cherkessia Republic; Dagestan Republic, Nogay, Tarumovka, Kizlyar, and Babayurt districts; Chechnya Republic, Shelkovskaya district; Stavropol District, Neftekumsk, Mineral’nyye Vody, and Kochubeyevskoye counties. Also in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan.
child.alt-names: Karanogai, Kubanogai, Nogaitsy, Nogalar, Nogay, Noghai, Noghay, Noghaylar

child.pub-comments: Population: 87,100 in Russian Federation (2010 census), decreasing. Population total all countries: 87,410. Ethnic population: 90,700 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Home, community. All ages, but many children shift to other languages at school age (2007). Positive attitudes. Most fluent in Karachai [krc] and or Russian [rus]. Language Development: Most read and write Russian [rus]. Taught in primary and secondary schools.

child.geography: Kazakhstan: Also in China, Germany, Iran, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Russian Federation, Tajikistan, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 5,290,000 in Kazakhstan (1979 census). Population total all countries: 8,077,770. Writing: Arabic script, used in China and Iran. Braille script. Cyrillic script, used in Kazakhstan and Mongolia. Latin script, used in Turkey. Language Use: 98% speak Kazakh as L1. Positive attitudes. Increasing ethnic pride and feelings of Islamic brotherhood. Many also use Russian [rus] or Northern Uzbek [uzn]. Language Development: Increasing education in Kazakh. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Bible: 1820–2010. Statutory national language (1995, Constitution, Article 7(1)).

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,100,000 in Azerbaijan (2007 census). 4,000,000 monolinguals. Population total all countries: 7,324,270. Ethnic population: 6,230,000. Writing: Arabic script, used until 1920s. Braille script. Cyrillic script, widely used in Armenia. Latin script, official script in Azerbaijan since 1992. Language use: 8,000,000 L2 speakers. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught as L2 in Russian language schools. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1891–2004. Statutory national language (1995, Constitution, Article 21(1)).

child.geography: Iran: Northeast, north Khorasan Province, northwest of Mashhad. West dialect in Bojnurd area; north in Quchan aera (probably largest), south in Soltanabad area near Sabzevar.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Midway linguistically between Azerbaijani and Turkmen [tuk], but not a dialect of either. The Oghuz-Uzbek dialect of Uzbek, Northern [uzn] in Uzbekistan is reportedly a dialect. Different from Khorasani, a local Persian dialect in Khorasan. Population: 400,000 (1977 G. Doerfer). Langauge Use: Also use Farsi [pes]. Language Development: Radio programs.

child.geography: Moldova: Comrat, Ceadîr-Lunga, Basarabeasca, Taraclia and Vulcânsti areas and towns. Also in Bulgaria, Kazakhstan, Romania, Russian Federation, Ukraine.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Similar to Turkish [tur], but uses Russian Orthodox Christian religious vocabulary in contrast to Islamic vocabulary of Turkish. Population: 138,000 in Moldova (2000). Population total all countries: 173,920. Writing: Cyrillic script, primary usage. Greek script, used until 1957. Latin script, used in Romania. Language Use: 89% speak it as L1.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Turkey. Also in Bulgaria, Greece, Macedonia.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Distinct from Gagauz [gag] of Moldova, Bulgaria, and Romania. Population: 327,000 in Turkey (Johnstone 1993). 7,000 Surguch (1965) and 320,000 Yuruk. Population total all countries: 331,000. Writing: Greek script. Language Use: Probably no children.

child.geography: Turkey: Widespread as L1 or L2. Also in Australia, Austria, Azerbaijan, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Canada, Cyprus, Denmark, Egypt, El Salvador, Finland, France, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Honduras, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Macedonia, Netherlands, Romania, Russian Federation, Serbia, Sweden, Switzerland, Tajikistan, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 46,300,000 in Turkey (1987). Population total all countries: 50,733,420. Writing: Arabic script, no longer in use. Braille script. Greek script, no longer in use. Latin script, used since 1928 or 1929, primary usage. Language Use: Karamanli are Turkish-speaking Greeks. Language Development: Fully developed. Bible: 1827–2006. Statutory national language (1982, Constitution, Article 3).

child.geography: Turkmenistan. Also in Afghanistan, Germany, Iran, Iraq, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Pakistan, Russian Federation, Syria, Tajikistan, Turkey, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.alt-names: Trukhmen, Trukhmeny, Turkmani, Turkmanian, Turkmenler, Turkomans
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 3,430,000 in Turkmenistan (1995). Population total all countries: 7,560,560. Ethnic population: 3,470,000 (1995). Writing: Arabic script, used in Afghanistan and Iran. Cyrillic script, used in Turkmenistan, not used in Afghanistan. Latin script, official usage in Turkmenistan since 1991. Language Use: Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Poetry. Magazines. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Statutory national language (1992, Constitution, Article 13).

child.geography: China: Qinghai Province, Xunhua Salar and Hualong Hui autonomous counties; Gansu Province, Jishishan autonomous county; Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Yilli. Kazakh autonomous prefecture.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Spoken by descendants of an Oghuz-Turkic-speaking subtribe. Has an Oghuz Turkic base, and took on a medieval Chaghatay Turkic stratum through Central Asian contacts and finally acquired a stratum of features from local languages (1989 R. Hahn). Jiezi often seen as standard dialect. Population: 70,000 (2002), increasing. 10,000 monolinguals. Ethnic population: 105,000 (2000 census). Language Use: Some speakers of other languages in the area use Salar, especially men. Domestic, informal domains. All ages, but children less. Positive attitudes. Also use Chinese [cmn], Uyghur [uig], or Tibetan [bod]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 0%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Considered the standard.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Iran: Central Province, northeast of Arak.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Not a dialect of Azerbaijani [azb], as previously supposed. Distinct from other extant Turkish languages (Doerfer et al 1971). Different from Indo-Iranian Khalaj [kjf]. Population: 42,100 (2000). Language Use: All ages. Most also use Farsi [pes].

child.geography: Ukraine: Crimea. Also in Bulgaria, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Romania, Russian Federation, Turkey, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Sometimes confused with, but distinct from, Tatar [tat]. Population: 260,000 in Ukraine (2006 A. Goriainov). Population total all countries: 475,540. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script, official use since 1997. Language Use: Mostly the older generations speak it, but it could be shifting up in use. Language Development: Taught in a few schools. Two local universities have faculties of Crimean Tatar. Poetry. Newspapers. TV. Language of recognized nationality (2009, No. 1167-VI, AR Crimea Republic Constitution (amended), Articles 11-13), protected language.

child.geography: Iran: Southwest, Fars and South Kohgiluyeh va Boyerahmad provinces. Shiraz, Gachsaran, and Firuzabad are centers.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Similar to Azerbaijani [azb]. Population: 1,500,000 (1997). Writing: Arabic script. Language Use: 1,500,000 (1997). Language Development: Many can read Farsi well.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Kemerovo Province; Khakassia Republic; scattered in Russian Federation.
child.alt-names: Aba, Kondoma Tatar, Kuznets Tatar, Mras Tatar, Shortsy, Tom-Kuznets Tatar
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Different from Shor dialect of Khakas [kjh]. Population: 2,840 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 14,000. Writing: Cyrillic script, Altai missionaries developed first alphabet in 1880s. Latin script, used from 1930 to 1938. Language Use: Few domains except perhaps family. Mostly middle-aged or older (2007). Neutral to strongly positive attitudes. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Russian. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2000–2004.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Gorno-Altai Ao mountains, Mongolia and China border. Population: 57,400 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 67,200 (including Northern Altai [atv]). 2002 census excluded 2,400 Talangits and 2,650 Teleuts. Writing: Cyrillic script. Mongolian script. Language Use: Home, and with other Altai. All ages. All also use Russian [rus] except older adults as a contact language, for literature, and urban professional and cultural life. Language Development: Written Altai based on Southern Altai, but is rejected by Northern Altai children. Taught in primary schools as a medium in a few schools and as a subject in a few schools. Statutory provincial language in Altai Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: No intelligiblility of Northern Altai [atv].

child.alt-names: Altai-Kizhi, Altaj Kizi, Maina-Kizhi, Southern Altai
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Siberia, Tuva Republic. Also in China, Mongolia.
child.alt-names: Diba, Kök Mungak, Soyod, Soyon, Soyot, Tannu-Tuva, Tofa, Tokha, Tuba, Tuvan, Tuvia, Tuvin, Tuvinian, Tyva, Uriankhai, Uriankhai-Monchak, Uryankhai
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 254,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census), increasing. Population total all countries: 283,400. Writing: Cyrillic script. Langage Use: One of most vital minority languages in Siberia due to geographic isolation. Home, work, government. All ages. Neutral attitudes. Also use Russian [rus] or Mongolian [khk] near the border. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% in Russian (2007 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools. Bible: 2011. De facto language of provincial identity in Tuva Republic.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Sharp dialect differences.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Sakha Republic, near Arctic Ocean, middle Lena river, Aldan and Kolyma rivers, 3,220 km.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 450,000 (2010 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: L2 by some Evenki [evn], Even [eve], and Yukaghir [yux] people. All ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Russian used in higher education. Grammar. Statutory provincial language in Sakha Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.alt-names: Kamas, Karagass, Sayan Samoyed, Tofa, Tofalar

child.pub-comments: Population: 90 (2010 census). Less than 40 fluent speakers, same number of passive speakers (Salminen 2007). Ethnic population: 840 (2002 census). Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 A. Kibrik). Home. Older adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Khakassia Republic, north of Altai mountains; Krasnoyarsk District, north; Tuva Republic; scattered throughout Russia. Also in China.
child.alt-names: Abakan Tatar, Hakass, Khakhass, Xakas, Yenisei, Yennisej Tatar
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 42,600 in Russian Federation (2010 census). 1,500 monolinguals (2002 census). Spoken by about 10% of the population of Khakasia (Salminen 2007). Population total all countries: 42,610. Ethnic population: 75,600 in the Russian Federation (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Struggle to maintain culture and language. In some rural areas children learn it, but in cities Russian [rus] is typically the only language (Salminen 2007). Home, community. All ages. Positive attitudes. In urban areas marked interest in Khakas language revival. Rural speakers want their children to learn the national language for economic advancement. Also use Russian [rus] at work, school, public transport, government, and most written communication. Fewer young people speak Khakas than previous generations, but more children study it in school than 20 years ago. Language Devleopment: Literacy rate in L1: 50% (2007 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Russian. Khakas books often self-published and difficult to obtain. Taught in primary schools as medium in a few schools, as subject in about 100 schools. Taught in secondary schools as a subject in selected schools. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1995–2008. Statutory language of provincial identity in Khakassia Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.pub-comments: Teleut may be a separate language. No intelligiblility of Southern Altai [lt]. Population: 57,400 (2010 census). 2,000 Tuba, several thousand Kumandy, 2,000 Chalkan (Salminen 2007). Census includes Southern Altai [alt]. Ethnic population: 67,200 (including Southern Altai). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Home, community, media. Little transmission of language to children (2007). Also use Russian [rus].

child.geography: Russian Federation: Sakha Republic, Anabar district; Krasnoyarsk district, Dudinka and Khatange counties.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Contact language on Tajmyr Peninsula spoken by Evenki [evn], Nganasan [nio], and long-term Russian residents. Different from Yakut [sah]. Population: 1,050 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 7,260 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language use: Low vitality. Family, friends. All ages. Children still learn it. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Several publications in Dolgan. Bible portions: 1996–2002.

child.geography: China: Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Also in Afghanistan, Australia, Taiwan, Germany, India, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Pakistan, Russian Federation, Saudi Arabia, Tajikistan, Turkey, United States, Uzbekistan.
child.alt-names: Uighuir, Uighur, Uiguir, Uigur, Uygur, Weiwu’er, Wiga
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 8,400,000 in China (2000 census). Most are monolingual. 4,700,000 Central Uyghur, 1,150,000 Hotan, 25,000 Lop. Population total all countries: 8,791,610. Writing: Arabic script, official and primary usage in China, also used in Afghanistan. Cyrillic script, used in Kazakhstan, past usage in China. Latin script, used in China and Turkey. Language Use: Widely used in print media in Kashgar. Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Youth and intellectuals also use Chinese [cmn]; a few also use English [eng] or Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% in any language (2000 census, Uyghur nationality). Literacy based on Central Uyghur as spoken in the area between Yili (Ili) and Urumqi, and includes literates in Uyghur or Chinese or both. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1950. Statutory provincial language in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (1984, Ethnic Regional Autonomy Act, Articles 10 and 21).

child.geography: Uzbekistan: East of the Amu Darya; south Aral Sea area. Possibly in Munich, Germany. Also in Australia, China, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russian Federation, Tajikistan, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, United States.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Persian influence in language... Russian [rus] influences in grammar, use of loanwords, and script. Population: 16,500,000 in Uzbekistan (1995 UN). Population total all countries: 18,968,250. Writing: Arabic script, officially abandoned in 1927, used in China. Braille script. Cyrillic script, officially adopted in 1940. Latin script, officially adopted in 1927 and abandoned in 1940, used in China. Sogdian script, used in China. Language Use: Vigorous. Turks of Fergana and Samarkand speak Uzbek. Uzbek-speaking Gypsy communities in Russian central Asia. All ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught in primary and secondary schools. Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Statutory national language (1995, [amended] Official Language Law, 3561-XI, Article 1).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Oghuz may be a dialect of Khorasani Turkish [kmz] in Turkey rather than Uzbek.

child.geography: China: Northwest Gansu Province, Sunan Yugur autonomous county near Zhangye (Kanchow).
child.alt-names: Sari Yogur, Sarig, Sarygh Uygur, Sary-Uighur, Ya Lu, Yellow Uighur, Yugu, Yuku
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 4,600 (Bradley 2007). Ethnic population: 7,000 (Bradley 2007). Language Use: Decreasing use. Religion, some commerce, oral literature. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% (2000 census, Yugur nationality). Written Chinese is in use.

child.geography: China: Southwest Xinjiang Autonomous Region, Hetian, Luopu, Moyu, Shache, Yingjisha, and Shulekuche counties; Kashgar area, Yengixar (Shule) town, Hanalik and Paynap villages, and Gewoz village near Hoban.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 6,570 (2000). Language Use: Home. Uyghur [uig] spoken to outsiders. Has the same grammar as Uyghur [uig] but much Persian [pes] vocabulary. Some consider it a dialect of Uyghur, others an Iranian language heavily influenced by Uyghur.

child.geography: China: Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Ili Kazak autonomous prefecture, Tekes, Nilka, Xinyuan, Gongliu, Zhaosu, and other counties, Ili valley near Kuldja. Also in Kazakhstan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 120 in China (1980 R. Hahn), decreasing. The language of about 30 families (Salminen 2007). Language Use: Younger generations are shifting to Kazakh [kaz] or Uygur [uig] (2007). Older adults. Also use Kazakh [kaz] or Uyghur [uig].

child.geography: Afghanistan: Faryab, Saripul, Jawzjan, Balkh, Samangan, Baghlan, Kunduz, Takhar, and Badakhshan provinces, in Maimana, Sheberghan, Aqcha, and Saripul towns. Also in Pakistan, Turkey.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Somewhat intelligible of, but differences in grammar from, Northern Uzbek [uzn]. Many loan words from Dari [prs]. Population: 2,910,000 in Afghanistan (2011 UNSD), increasing. 1,000,000 monolinguals. Population total all countries: 2,961,980. Ethnic population: 2,910,000. Writing: Arabic script. Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Mostly positive attitudes. City dwellers also use Dari [prs]; village dwellers have limited ability in Dari. A few also use Southern Pashto [pbt]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Dari [prs]. L1 Literacy in larger towns increasing among younger population. The Afghanistan Ministry of Education has produced Southern Uzbek textbooks for grades 1–3; planned through 12th grade. Taught in secondary schools. Poetry. Magazines. Newspapers. New media. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2004–2006. Statutory language of provincial identity in Fariab, Jawzjan, Saripul, other northern provinces (2004, Constitution, Article 16(2)).

child.geography: Russian Federation: Chuvashia Republic, east of Moscow, near Volga river. About half live in towns. Also in Estonia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,043,000 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 1,077,420. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: 200,000 L2 speakers. Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Bible: 2010. Statutory language of provincial identity in Chuvash Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.pub-comments: Population: 97,700 in Georgia (2000). Population total all countries: 192,700. Writing: Cyrillic script. Greek script, occasional usage. Language Use: Few child speakers (2007). Language Develpment: Grammar.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Sakhalin Province, Poronajsk district, Poronajsk town, Gastello and Vakhrushev settlements; Nogliki district, Val village, Nogliki settlement. Also in Japan.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 47 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 50. Ethnic population: 350. Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 A. Kibrik). Home. Older adults high proficiency, middle generation partial proficiency, children/adolescents no ability in Orok. Youngest fluent speakers over 50. Language Development: A project to create a literary norm in Cyrillic script and teach the language at elementary schools has recently been launched in cooperation with Japanese scholars (Salminen 2007). Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Extreme far east, confluence of Amur and Ussuri rivers, scattered in Ussuri valley; Sikhote-Alin, centered in Amur valley below Khabarovsk. Also in China.
child.alt-names: Gold, Goldi, Heche, Hezhe, Hezhen, Nanaj
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 1,350 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 1,390. Ethnic population: 12,200. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Severely endangered. Mainly older adults. Neutral to mildly positive attitudes. Motivated to use Russian [rus]. Those under 40 consider Nanai unhelpful in life. Older generation pessimistic about possibility of preservation. Also use Russian [rus]. Some elderly may also use Chinese [cmn]. Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1884–2002.

child.alt-names: Hoche, Hol-Chih, Olch, Olcha, Olchis, Ulcha, Ulchi, Ulych

child.pub-comments: Population: 150 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 2,900. Language Use: Only 25% claim to speak L1 (2002 census). Rapid decrease in use. Traditional culture (funerals), oral ethnic storytelling, family. Youth prefer Russian [rus]. All middle-aged or older (2007). Most also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Dictionary.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Siberia far east; Khabarovsk District, Lazo area, Gvasiugi settlement; Nanai [gld] language area, Arsenievo settlement; Primorsky District, Pozharsky area, Krasny Yar, Olon, and Sobolinyi settlements; Ternei area, Agzu settlement; Krasnoarmeisky area, Roschino, Dalniy Kut, and Melnichnoye settlements.
child.alt-names: Kiakala, Tazy, Ude, Udegeis, Udeghe, Udehe

child.pub-comments: Population: 100 (2010 census). 80 or less L1 users (Vakhtin 2001). Ethnic population: 1,660. Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: hifting rapidly to Russian [rus] (2007). Home. Elderly only. Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

child.geography: China: Heilongjiang Province, a few Manchu-speaking villages in Aihui and Fuyu counties.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 20 (Bradley 2007). Some additional semi-speakers in 3 remote villages (Bradley 2007). Ethnic population: 10,680,000 (2000 census). Writing: Mongolian script, Manchu style, used since 1599. Mongolian script, Old Manchu style, no longer in use. Language Use: Long extinct among the mainly urbanized Manchu, but still studied in an ongoing scholarly tradition (2007). Older adults, 50 and older. Positive attitudes. All bilingual. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Written Chinese in common use. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 50 read and write. Literacy rate in L2: 82%. Dictionary.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Inherently intelligible of Manchu [mnc]. Population: 30,000 (2000 A. Jun). Few monolinguals. Ethnic population: 189,000 (2000 census). Writing: Mongolian script, Sibe style. Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages in rural areas. Positive attitudes. Also use Chinese [cmn], Uyghur [uig], Kazakh [kaz], English [eng], or Russian [rus]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 52%. Taught in primary schools. Newspapers. Radio programs. Dictionary. Grammar. Statutory language of provincial identity in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (1984, Ethnic Regional Autonomy Act, Articles 10 and 21).

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Dialectal differences within Evenki are small and the case for regarding Evenki and Orochen as separate languages is weak (Salminen 2007). Population: 11,000 in China (Salminen 2007). Population total all countries: 17,130. Ethnic population: 30,500 (2000 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: Other speakers in the area also use Evenki. All domains. Very few children except among the Khamnigan. Positive attitudes. Bilinguals use Mongolian [mvf], Daur [dta], Chinese [cmn], or Oroqen [orh] as L2. Written Mongolian and Chinese used as literary languages. Herdsmen use Mongolian as L2; farmers use Chinese. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 96%, literacy in any language (2000 census, Ewenki nationality). Radio programs. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1995.

child.pub-comments: Dialectal differences within Evenki are small.

child.pub-comments: Population: 1,200 (Li Fengxiang and Whaley 2009). 800 are monolingual. 30% of ethnic group (Salminen 2007). Only 12 fluent speakers in 1990, all over 65 yrs (Li Fengxiang and Whaley 2009). Ethnic population: 8,200 (2000 census). Language Use: Kumarchen dialect has some child speakers; Birarchen is moribund (2007). All domains. Mostly middle-aged or elderly (2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], Mongolian [mvf], Russian [rus], Evenki [evn], or Daur [dta]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 97% in any language (2000 census, Oroqen nationality). Radio programs.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Many dialects divided into two main groups: Western and Eastern Even. Population: 5,660 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 19,100 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script, two orthographical standards, limited usage. Language use: Strongest in Sakha (Beryozovka, Sebyan-Kyuly) and Northern Magadan Oblast (Seymchan). Evens learn the language of ethnicities around them, and switch to that language when a non-Even is present. Few domains. Mainly older adults. Positive attitudes. All are bilingual or multilingual in Russian [rus], Yakut [sah] or Koryak [kpy] (Salminen 2007). Language Development: Some literature available. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1880–2001.

child.pub-comments: Population: 6,000. Very few monolinguals. Ethnic population: 24,500, including 16,500 Jishishan and 8000 Tongren. Language Use: Religion, local administration, home; for Tongren, not used for religion. Tongren: all ages. Positive attitudes, except in Tongren. Also use Amdo Tibetan [adx] or Mandarin [cmn]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 44% (2000 census, Baoan nationality). No written language; no desire for one. Amdo Tibetan is local LWC. Chinese required to excel in school and find a good job. Dictionary. Grammar.

child.pub-comments: Dongren Huzhu considered the standard. Dialects reported not inherently mutually intelligible. Population: 152,000 (2000 census). Very few monolinguals. Ethnic population: 190,000. Writing: latin script, Pinyin-based. Language Use: Varies with location. Positive attitudes. Most also use Chinese [cmn] or Tibetan [bod]. Written Chinese or Tibetan are used. 30,000 people have shifted to Chinese. Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 2,000 can read, 200 can write. Literacy rate in L2: 77% literate in any language (2000 census, Tu nationality). Poetry. Magazines. Films. Dictionary. Grammar.

Mongolian script, used prior to 1941 with a resurgence since the 1990s. Phags-pa script, no longer in use. Tibetan script, no longer in use. Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. All ages. Language Development: Taught in all schools. Taught in primary and secondary schools. Poetry. Magazines. Newspapers. New media. Radio programs. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1990. Statutory national language (1992, Constitution, Article 8(1)).

child.pub-comments: Largely intelligible of Halh Mongolian [khk], but there are phonological and important loanword differences. Population: 3,380,000 in China (1982). 2,500,000 are monolingual. Population includes 299,000 Chakhar, 317,000 Bairin, 1,347,000 Khorain, 593,00 Karachin, 123,000 Ordos, 34,000 Ejine. Writing: Mongolian script. Phags-pa script, no longer in use. Language Use: Vigorous. Chinese living in the area can also speak it. All domains. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. About 70,000 can also speak Uyghur [uig] or Kazakh [kaz]. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 71%. Taught in primary and secondary schools. Magazines. Newspapers. Radio programs. TV. Grammar. Bible: 2003. Statutory provincial working language in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region and other places (1984, Ethnic Regional Autonomy Act, Articles 10 and 21).

child.geography: Mongolia: Northeast, especially Russian (Republic of Buryatia) border.
child.alt-names: Burraad, Buriat-Mongolian, Buryat, Mongolian Buriat, Northern Mongolian
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Buriat in Mongolia is a variety of Khori and differs considerably from Buriat [bxu] of China and the Russian Federation. Influenced by and mutually intelligible with standard (Halh) Mongolian [khk]. Population: 45,100 (2010 census), decreasing. Writing: Cyrillic script. Latin script, used in 1930s. Mongolian script, used until 1917. Language Use: Also use Halh Mongolian [khk] as literary language. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Halh Mongolian [khk]. Films. Videos. Grammar. Bible portions: 2004. Some books in Buriat. Not a literary language in Mongolia.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Main dialect in the Russian Federation
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.geography: Russian Federation: Siberia, Republic of Buryatia, east of Lake Baikal, bordering on Mongolia.
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Literary dialect differs considerably from those in Mongolia and China, which are influenced by other languages. Population: 219,000 (2010 census). Ethnic population: 445,200 (2002 census). Writing: Cyrillic script. Language Use: poken even between Buriat speakers (Salminen 2007). Home, community. All ages. Neutral attitudes. Younger people in the cities also use Russian [rus]. Language Development: Those on both sides of Lake Baikal are fully literate in the literary variety. Newspapers. Bible: 1846. Statutory language of provincial identity in Buriat Republic (1993, Constitution, Article 68(2)).

child.pub-comments: Speakers in Russian Federation appear to understand each other well.

child.geography: China: Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, Hulun-Buyr district, near Russia (Siberia) and Mongolia borders.
child.alt-names: Ba’erhu-Buliyate, Bargu Buriat, Buriat-Mongolian, Buryat, Northeastern Mongolian, Northern Mongolian
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Differs from Buriat of Mongolia [bxm] and the Russian Federation [bxr] due to influences of other languages. Population: 65,000 (1982 census). 47,000 New Bargu, 14,000 Old Bargu, 4,500 Buriat. Language Use: Shifting to Mongolian. Language Development: Written Mongolian is the literary language.

child.geography: Russian Federation: Kalmykia Republic, Volga-Don steppes northwest of the Caspian, north of the Caucasus. Dörböt dialect: mostly west Kalmykia; Torgut dialect: mostly east, lower Volga region, Astrakhan Province. Also in China, Taiwan, Germany, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia (Oirat), United States.
child.alt-names: European Oirat, Kalmack, Kalmuck, Kalmuk, Kalmytskii Jazyk, Khalli, Oirat, Qalmaq, Volga Oirat, Western Mongolian
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: The modern literary language is mainly based on the Torgut dialect, though it incorporates a large number of concessions to Dörböt. Diverged from other Mongolian languages. Called Kalmyk in the Russian Federation; Oirat in China and Mongolia; in the United States, Kalmyk not heavily influenced by Russian [rus]. Different from other varieties in China called Oirat [xal], which are sometimes called Asiatic Oirat. In Mongolia, some scholars consider Oirat to be a dialect of Halh Mongolian [khk]. Population: 80,500 in Russian Federation (2010 census). Population total all countries: 360,500. Ethnic population: 174,000. Writing: Cyrillic script, adopted in 1924, used in Russia and Mongolia. Mongolian script, Todo style, used in China. Language Use: 91% speak it as L1. A few children learn the language. Also use Russian [rus]. Tibetan [bod] is religious language.

child.geography: China: Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, Hulun Buir league, Hailar prefecture, Morin Dawa (Molidawa) Daur autonomous banner, Oroqen autonomous banner and Ewenki autonomous banner; Heilongjiang Province, Nenjiang prefecture, Fuyu and Nehe counties; Qiqihar prefecture, Qiqihar city; northwest Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Tacheng prefecture (Ili dialect). Also in Mongolia.
child.alt-names: Daguor, Dagur, Dawar, Dawo’er, Tahuerh, Tahur
child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.pub-comments: Population: 96,100 in China (1999 D. Ying), decreasing. 24,270 monolinguals. 35,000 Buteha dialect, 35,000 Qiqiha’er dialect, 15,500 Haila’er dialect, 4500 Ili dialect. Ethnic population: 132,000 (2000 census). Writing: Cyrillic script, no longer in use. Han script, Simplified variant. Latin script. Mongolian script, Manchu style, used since the Qing dynasty. Language Use: In Hulun Buir the language is being retained well; in Heilongjiang not transmitted to children among most groups (Bradley 2007). All domains. Mainly adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Chinese [cmn] or Mongolian [mvf]. A few also use Evenki [evn], Kazakh [kaz], Oroqen [orh], or Manchu [mnc]. Reportedly high and widespread bilingualism in Chinese, the school language. Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 97% (2000 census, Daur nationality). Some literacy in Mongolian among those 30 to 50 years of age in Hala’er. Poetry. Radio programs. Films. Dictionary. Grammar. Statutory language of provincial identity in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, Hulun Buir League (1984, Ethnic Regional Autonomy Act, Articles 10 and 21).
